Award.AwardTitle: Metal Platforms for the Photoactivation of Metal-Hydride, -Halide and -Oxo Bonds
Award.AbstractNarration: The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation will support the research program of Daniel Nocera at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Dr. Nocera and his students will investigate the development of catalysts for the photochemical activation of small molecules, including water and hydrogen halides, useful in the generation of solar fuels. The focus of the research is on the expansion of the reactivity of metal complexes to include multi-electron transfer processes for the activation of small molecules relevant to solar fuel production. A combination of synthetic, spectroscopic characterization, and photocatalytic cycle development studies will be pursued. The fundamental understanding resulting from this research will enable the development of solar based renewable energy schemes. Students will be trained in the fundamental science and the public issues relevant to these renewable energy questions. Outreach to the public forms a large part of the work of this research group.

Intellectual Merit

Energy storage is the single most critical challenge to the widespread implementation of renewable energy. Though renewable energy sources like wind and solar are approaching costs similar to those of fossil-fuel-based sources, they are intermittent and hence a cost-effective storage method is also needed for their implementation. Energy storage is important for non-renewable energy applications in that it offers flexibility to the grid operator and reduces costs by minimizing the need for gas peaking plants or costly transmission network build-outs that are required only to support peak demand. Pronounced demand is expected to develop in those countries and regions where renewable energy deployment is significant (e.g. China, U.S., Germany, Italy) or fossil fuel prices remain durably high (Japan, Korea), or both. The accompanying figure shows market sizes approaching 1 trillion U.S.D. that have been projected by analysts with regard to global demand for grid storage [1]. Despite this demand, good solutions for storage remain limited. The size of the market, together with the goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, provides an imperative for the continued exploration of the basic science of energy storage.

Most current methods of energy storage are characterized by low energy densities and consequently they present formidable challenges for the large-scale implementation of renewable energy sources. As the PI of this project has documented in a recent review [2], the energy density of fuels is minimally ≥102 times larger than any other storage methods, including batteries. As the reaction of H2 with CO2 to make any fuel is effectively thermoneutral [3], the key challenge, from a solar energy conversion point of view, is to obtain H2 renewably. Members of the project team have focused on two H2-generating reactions,

2H2O + light  →  2H2  +  O2                                                 (1)

2HX + light  →  H2  +  X2                                                       (2)

Both HX and H2O splitting store approximately the same amount of energy per electron (E = 1.23 eV and 1.36 eV for H2O and HCl, respectively). Whereas the utility of water splitting is well-documented (equation (1)), the utility of HX splitting (equation (2)) is less discussed, even though this conversion can be exploited for storing solar energy in the form of a redox flow battery [4] or chemical fuel [5]. They (i) are multielectron, (ii) involve coupling electrons to protons and (iii) involve the formation of high-energy bonds: H–H, X–X and O–O. Reactions (1) and (2) have three characteristics. More generally, this NSF project focuses on understanding the conversion of energy-poor molecules to energy-rich molecules by defining the fundamental principles of these proton-coupled, multielectron, H–H, X–X and O–O bond-forming reactions.
